Dear Tia M. Cobb:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Bed checks are not being completed in a timely manner.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 3, 2024. Supervisor 1 reported she has not seen or heard
any concerns about staff not completing room checks. She noted she
has witnessed staff perform room checks at variable intervals not to
exceed fifteen minutes. Supervisor 1 reported that when she checked
in with the youth, they never reported concerns about staff not
checking in on them when they were in their room.
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were separately
interviewed face to face at the facility on October 3, 2024. Youth
A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D reported staff are always checking
in on them when they are in their bedroom. They reported when it is
bedtime, staff will take a flashlight and shine it in their room to check
in on them. All the youth reported that staff checks on them every ten
to fifteen minutes, and they noted these checks are done at random
times. They reported staff write their checks on the pink sheet
outside their room. Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D reported
they had no concerns about staff not doing room checks. It should be
noted all four youth reside in different pods at the facility. Youth A
resides on Pod A, Youth B resides on Pod H, Youth C resides on
Pod B, and Youth D resides on Pod E.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were separately interviewed face to face at
the facility on October 3, 2024. Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported they are
float staff that work on the second shift, which is from 3pm to 11pm.
They both reported when a youth is in their rooms it is the
responsibility of staff to do checks on the youth in variable intervals
not to exceed fifteen minutes. Staff 2 reported the youth go into their
rooms for bed around 9pm and one of her job responsibilities is to
walk around the unit at variable intervals, check the youth in their
room, and mark the check time on the pink sheet. She reported she
tries to do room checks about every twelve minutes. Staff 1 reported
the times all need to be random so that the youth does not know they
are being checked on to make sure they are safe. Staff 1 and Staff 2
2

both stated they do not have concerns about staff not completing
room checks and have not heard of these concerns before.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on October 23, 2024. Staff 3
reported he works third shift at the facility, which is from 11pm-7am.
He reported his main duty is do room monitoring since all the youth
are in their rooms during his shift. Staff 3 reported he checks on the
youth every twelve minutes. He reported that he will check to see the
youth in their room, make sure they are breathing and safe, and then
mark the time of the check on the room monitoring forms. Staff 3
reported he has not heard any concerns or seen any concerns of
staff not completing room checks on the youth.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on October 24, 2025. Staff 4
reported she works third shift at the facility. She reported her main
role is to check on youth while they are sleeping since they are in
their room majority of her shift. Staff 4 reported she is told to check in
on the youth every twelve to fourteen minutes and note it on the
room monitoring forms. She reported she checks on the youth every
twelve minutes exactly. Staff 4 reported she does not have any
concerns of staff at the facility not completing room checks.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 3, 2024. Supervisor 2 reported one of her job
responsibilities is to watch the control room monitors. She stated
within that role she watches the live cameras of the different pods for
safety purposes. Supervisor 2 reported she has never seen concerns
about staff not checking in on youth when they are in their room. She
stated she has watched staff complete room checks in variable
intervals not to exceed fifteen minutes. Supervisor 2 reported she
has also not heard of concerns of staff not completing room checks
in a timely manner.
Video Reviewed:
The agency reported video footage could not be retrieved from
cameras due to a power surge that occurred, and video content
could not be retrieved for September 2024.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility’s Room Monitoring Policy- This policy notes the
staff are to use the Room Monitoring Record Form (Pink
Sheet) when you are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff. The staff are to perform variable interval,
eyes on check of the youth. The time between the variable
interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
- Room Monitoring Forms- Consultant reviewed the following
random dated room monitoring forms
3

form noted checks were completed every twelve
minutes exactly.

o September 10, 2024- Pod F Room Monitoring From-

o September 15, 2024- Pod A Room Monitoring Form-
From the hours of 2pm to 3:48 pm the room monitoring

o September 18, 2024- Pod G Room Monitoring Form-

o September 24, 2024- Pod C Room Monitoring Form-
From the hours of 2:30pm to 3:08pm checks were

o September 30, 2024- Pod E Room Monitoring Form-
From the hours of 10pm to 6am the room monitoring
4

form noted checks were completed every twelve
minutes exactly.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance of completing room checks
within variable intervals as it was found in documentation and
interviews that staff have been completing room checks that did
not vary in intervals.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Program Statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Facility's Room Monitoring Policy does not algin with the seclusion
variance.
Investigation Interviews:
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
November 8, 2024. Administrator reported the Room Monitoring
Policy needs to be updated as it notes the youth would be secured in
their room for headcounts. She reported the facility does have a
seclusion variance to only allow seclusion be used to prevent life-
threatening injury when all other interventions are ineffective.
Administrator reported currently the youth are not secured in their
room for headcounts, showers, medical observations, or timeouts.
She reported the youth typically keeps their door open but if they
choose to close the door then the staff will use the room monitoring
form to document for room checks.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility’s Room Monitoring Policy- This policy notes the
staff are to use the Room Monitoring Record Form (Pink
Sheet) when you are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff. The staff are to use the form during:
“Headcount- when youth are in their rooms with the door
secured for building headcount procedure; Showers- when
youth are in their rooms out of direct line-of-site of staff for PM
showers; Medical Observation- when youth are in their room
out of direct-line of site of staff for medical observation/ watch;
Time-out- when their rooms are out of direct line-of-site of
staff for time-out with the door ajar.”
5

- Room Monitoring Forms- This form notes staff are to mark
the reason for use of room monitoring form for the following
reasons: 1. Night Watch, 2. Head Count, 3. Medical Watch,
and 4. Individual Reflection.
- Seclusion Variance Approval dated 09/27/2024- The facility
was provided to use seclusions as a temporary response to
prevent life-threatening injury or serious bodily harm when
other interventions are ineffective.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance of their Room Monitoring
Policy noting a youth would be secured within their bedroom
during a headcount which does not align with the seclusion
variance approval directives.
Technical Assistance: The facility was provided the technical
assistance to ensure the room monitoring form aligns with the
room monitoring policy reasons to use the form.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
